Throughout 2012, I've promised to identify the four (4) strategic pillars of the GOP: micro-targeting (esp. regulatory agency budgets and voters already on the rolls), federal and state power grabs and asset privatization, blame (unity and victory through fear), and a compliant media.

David's column, elegant, erudite, formally structured as contrasts, mixed with fantasy, line by line, it falls squarely as blame.

True to form, it's one of the Republican's Big Four.

Generalizations, are really hard to nail. They inevitably fail when history is contemporized, or when the vast differences in material and culture are ignored or over subscribed.

As an example, little of what David Brooks describes, applies to the world's fifth largest economy, the 11 states of the old Confederacy, the deep South of segregation and civil rights, a place of shadow that produced the nation's highest number of black election officials in Mississippi, one of the poorest states in the Union, and the home of a Nobel prize winner in literature--a region whose shift from Democratic to Republic fuels our politics more than an "adolescent" early industrial economy, a vast land of black and white share croppers who could not avoid the "moral horror at debt," which by political and social design was their quarter of life. Yet this region (not the agricultural and industrial Midwest and Northeast) fueled the American dream through the export of rice that fed northern Europe.

Others in the comments will take on the column's politics; I simply want to point out its glaring omissions, its ethnocentrism, and its main fallacy: misplacing concreteness (Alfred North Whitehead's contribution to logic).

I do agree with two of its descriptions: "today, we have oligarchic economies." And David's description of the administration's reading of history more aptly applies to his column: its "superficial similarities are outweighed by vast differences."

Hope you're right, but I think the President will barely scrape by.  Fortunately, he will take nothing for granted.

It would seem that Romney is falling for the bait and will be running as the "Bain" of the middle and working classes. A rich man himself, surrounded by other rich Republican men, he will rant on about "government dependency" while the Democrats repeat that Romney will destroy Social Security, Medicare and other popular social benefit programs.  Romney will be subject to lots of personal attacks as a rich, insensitive lout like Bush One, but these will have more force because of Romney's many years as an "acquire, layoff, selloff, destroy" corporate predator.  Result: Romney loses to Obama by a hefty margin despite high unemployment and the economy being generally disheveled.

My daughter is multiply handicapped--blind and developmentally disabled. Fortunately, we have resources to support her. However, her good friend from school is also blind and has cerebral palsy. She's not developmentally disabled. Recently she has developed diabetes. She is amazing, learning how to monitor her own blood sugar and give herself insulin injections. Her mother, and caretaker, has recently died and she lives with her brother. The young woman has great resilience. She receives SSI for her disability and support for her diabetes through an occasional visiting nurse. Her brother can only find work two days a week. The two of them make ends meet, but only barely. Our government needs to support this kind of person. To balance our budget on the backs of the handicapped is evidence of an immoral society.

The only thing I need to know about the chronic liar and flip-flopper, Willard Romney, is the picture of him and his fellow capitalism criminals stuffing $100 bills in their mouths and pockets!  The GOP stands for "Greed Over the People" and Willard Romney is a classic example of that greed!

Let's talk about the "welfare" hedge fund managers get, paying 15% on their income while the rest of us have to pay the regular income tax rates.

Lets talk about the LBOs he's responsible for which destroyed jobs, enriching himself and bankers alongs the way, while encouraging the culture of debt which had to be bailed out by the "entitlement" programs for the rich and well connected.

But can we please stop talking about how the poor, powerless, and disenfranchised are the source of our problems?

Kick the poor; wonderful social policy. Mr. Romney is a Christian, so perhaps we should remind him that "Even as you do unto the least of my brethren, you do unto me." A rather different social policy.

I've been poor, worked my way through state colleges over seven years -- laboring in factories, UPS loading docks, restaurants. Then graduate school. Now, multiple degrees and prestigious universities later I'm prosperous. What I learned along the way, however, is sympathy for the less advantaged, not contempt for them. For Mr. Romney to preach that help to the less fortunate creates "dependence" is morally blind. I don't think a morally blind man is really what we need in the White House.

It's just more evidence that Republican hopefuls, most certainly including Romney, are completely out of touch with reality. I work with both disabled individuals and others who depend on Programs like SSI, Medicaid and food stamps to survive. Many of them are not people of color, nor are they by any means lazy. One of my clients in particular is a caucasian mother of two who until recently was employed full time. Unfortunately, since losing her job several months ago, she has had tremendous difficulty even paying her rent, and has had to rely on largesse from local churches to supplement her very limited food stamp allotment to feed her kids. She would have had NO Christmas presents to give them had it not been for the generosity of local friends and non-profit organizations. By the way, she also applies for jobs every week, even though she has to expend tremendous energy just to keep her head above water. Is she "undeserving" of assistance? Or are these so-called entitlements providing a temporary helping hand until she is able to get back on her feet and become one of those who in turn helps someone else in need of assistance? To me, that's the picture of the way good government should work.
Romney is obviously out to destroy pay as you go generational cost shifting across the board.

The last line of the article is correct, "We are headed toward an ideological confrontation over the next 11 months of an intensity rarely seen in American political history."

Mitt has framed the issue and will get the chance to sell his vision to the American people. This election will either take back America to its core values or facilitate the path to European style socialism. It will produce just what this country needs, a president with a clear mandate to move in a strategic direction; as opposed to President Obama acting in office based on the false and mis-leading slogans of the 2008 campaign. "Hope and Change". Hope and change to what? He never said and the public created their own anti-Bush image of what was meant by that slogan. I've always thought that the 2008 was an intellectual "coup d'etat". So be it. Now we will have the chance to clearly see a difference and make an honest choice. I have no doubt that this will be the most important election in our lifetime.

Those of us who are of the 99% are just dogs to be tied to the top of the car on Willard's road trip to power. If we soil ourselves, just pull over for a minute, hose us down and get back on the road asap. Just so long as we:
1. Don't take up any space IN the car
2. Don't cost the driver anything during the cleanup

Why won't he release his tax returns? Did he not pay taxes? Did he get a refund? What is he hiding?
And not to change the subject, but I read recently about the staggering amount of wealth that the Walton (Walmart) family has accumulated, and then I read how many full-time Walmart employees have to rely on food stamps for their survival. Is this what Romney is talking about when he says that Obama wants a society where everyone has the same outcome? To me it seems more like the greedy taking advantage of their fellow Americans.
If there were jobs to fill our pockets, then entitilements would not be the life-line that they are now.

We tried punishing people into productivity without rewards, it is called slavery.  The safety net programs were never meant to be a goal, they were to be a temporary haven.  What never was accomplished was a program that lead people out of poverty by providing opportunity and incentives to modify outlooks.  Poverty is not very inspiring and once you are down, the Romney's of the world start punishing you as you have no assets to take, no labor to exploit.  A capital driven society has no use for poor people.  Welfare for capitalists is completely different because they are not poor.
Romney promises to take the nation private in the biggest leveraged buy out in history, finishing what Reagan started when he outsourced government to Exxon, News Corp and Walmart.

Mittney is the entitled, Harvard-educated scion of a powerful Mormon family. His complete inability to show empathy, as manifest is his glee over laying off workers and showing off dollars, suggests borderline psychopathy.

I believe many (if not most) people in this country lack basic knowledge of the amounts, terms and restrictions on "welfare" eligibility.  I regularly see letters to the editor and comments online that state that people are tired of their taxes going to support able-bodied people who choose not to work. But there isn't such a program, at least not since Clinton's welfare reform act of 1996. The Supplemental Security Income gives a small monthly payment and Medicaid to disabled (meaning, they are not able to work) and low income people under 65, and to low income people 65 or over.  Medicaid eligibility is automatically established for people who are SSI eligible, but that is not a cash program.   The old much-reviled Aid to Families With Dependent Children Program was eliminated in 1996 and replaced with Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, which allows very low income parents to get cash assistance to support their families.  The TANF program requires parents to look for work or engage in job training programs, and there is a five year limitation on receipt of these benefits.  It is very difficult to find housing and pay for the necessities of life on a TANF allotment, but a still popular belief has parents choosing not to work and get paid by the government to crank out babies.   And the people who rail against the TANF program tend to be the same people who want Planned Parenthood to go away.

There is no better example of how bankrupt today's GOP is than the efforts of that party to restrict voting. A political party that was interested in promoting the democratic values that make our country great would seek to increase voting, and let the chips fall where they may on election day. Instead, the GOP cowers in fear from the electorate, and chooses to combine a suppression of democracy with the money from conservative sugar daddies in an attempt to gain political power regardless of the cost to our democracy.

While these GOP efforts are focused primarily on reducing the vote among members of Democratic leaning groups, such as students, African Americans, the poor, and Latinos, the undermining of democracy being carried out by the GOP affects us all by weakening the fundamental core of our political system. It is up to all of us to fight back by protesting against the restrictive laws that the GOP is trying to pass, helping register voters, and making sure that everyone who wants to vote on election day is able to comply with whatever hurdles the GOP is able to put up.

Romney's rhetoric sounds like it was lifted right out of the script for LDS politicians in Utah. Most members of the legislature and the governor espouse the same beliefs. They HATE the federal government, and the righteousness of hard work is a core teaching. In Utah the assumption is that if you're poor or disabled you can join the church and meet your needs there. It's a great strategy for increasing membership.

If the Republicans succeed in gutting Social Security and Medicare, will Tea Party seniors, of whom there is a sizable number, wake up? Or do they want to disenfranchise those of us who are unemployed and approaching the age of eligibility? Maybe they see us as competition for increasingly scarce resources. "I've got mine so tough luck!"

Romney is right, but only in part. School lunches and Medicaid are not similar things. People do need to eat and the cost of food does not rise drastically from year to year. But the cost of medical procedures does rise. The cost of Medicaid increased by 35 billion in just ONE year from 2009 to 2010. That equals five times the budget of the National Science Foundation or, 7 million Pell grants to college students. When government spends money for basic needs that is good and when government spends money on development, education and research, that too is good.

But throwing money down the well to keep people alive for a few months longer, we cannot afford it. For instance, Medicaid $75,000 a year on dialysis for an illegal immigrant. What other country would do something so insane? 15 US citizens could get Pell grants for that same $75,000.

It's hard to imagine who Mr. Romney thinks he's fooling- I suppose the American public? A legacy politician, a man who had to admit he'd never had to do without a luxury, much less a necessity, in a his entire life during on of the GOP dates, who has never created anything except 5 children, several gigantic mansions and a large personal fortune- oh, except for the health care laws that he was for before he was against them- he sees himself as the man to lead the US back to glory? And by destroying what tiny social safety net our society provides?

Mitt Romney is not credible at all, nor is anyone in the Republican field. I count myself among the many who are disappointed with President Obama, but I think that's precisely why we should return him to the white House next November. The GOP is off the rails, but the Democrats aren't far behind. They need to stand strongly with the people to turn this country around.

What a disgusting you-know-what! In Romney's world innocent children and those who care for them are not "entitled" to food, adequate shelter, or health care. In other words, the babies, once they're born, do not matter. Who cares about the die-off?

Romney himself is "entitled", in the other sense of the word; i.e., he was born with a silver spoon in his mouth. Yes, he may be disciplined and a hard worker and thus is in his own sense of the word "deserving", but he wouldn't have made it nearly so far if he hadn't been lucky to have been born rich.

Who could possibly fault Mitt Romney for his ideological affirmation of the benefits that will correctly accrue to those Americans who exercise right-minded decisions in his proposed Opportunity Society?

Gov. Romney's life shows the rewards reaped by, for example, asutely choosing parents who will enhance one's prospects for a secure economic future. Credit Mitt for having the foresight and ambition to choose George Romney, an American Motors president, three time Michigan governor, and Republican presidential candidate, and Lenore Lafount Romney, whose father was appointed by Calvin Coolidge as federal radio commissioner, as his father and mother. Without this moral character and resolve, Mitt might have gone astray, choosing instead less estimable parents from the working classes, or parents without solid social connections in high places.

Such lack of planning might have resulted in Mitt's not securing draft deferements during the Vietnam war for his missionary work in France and studies at Harvard. As a combat grunt in Vietnam, Mitt could have been killed, wounded or disabled for the resto of his life. Such a tragedy was readily avoided because of Mitt's insightful early life choices. Decisions always have consequences, and the Opportunity Society will reward all who live by its moral prescriptions. So, don't critize Mitt for his advocacy of a social system that has worked so well for him and could, if you have the right stuff, work as well for you.

Instead of thinking of these programs as "entitlements" or "welfare", how about "investment"? They are proof of our value system and belief that investing in our most precious resource, our population, is critical for our country's best prospect of sustainable peace and prosperity.

And to Romney's charge about creating an "Entitlement-based society", that's grotesque: in time of severe economic times which clearly these past three years have been, we depend on government, especially the federal government, to step it up. Further to this point, any comparative metrics on spending by an administration for these programs needs to be put into context of the prevailing health of the economy. If there's been increased spending in these areas over the past three years, that hasn't led to the bad economy: it's the other way around.

Stephen J. Johnson,

I would have recommended your comment another 86 times, had I been given the choice. "Meet the new boss; same as the old boss...."

Yes, we do currently borrow 40 cents on the dollar, but you're conveniently forgetting that 10 short years ago we were running in the black. And just what has changed since then?

1) Bush cut taxes, the 'gift that keeps on giving'
2) Not one, but two wars - the first time in US history ever that we had a war and a tax cut
3) A huge recession - which not only cuts government income (taxes - less income to tax), but also raises expenses (e.g. unemployment insurance)

Yeah, there was the stimulus, but that was small beans against the above three, and probably helped mitigate the recession enough to justify at least much of the expense anyway.

Let's fix those three, and then we can talk about health care (the big problem going forward). Oh, and by the way the trust fund IS real - unless you don't believe that US Treasury Bills are trustworthy.
